comments.text:
I'm not going to call you a racist or a redneck. I am going to respectfully 
tell you that I think you're misunderstanding some of the legal nuances 
here.

First of all, I'm not from Florida, different laws (regarding felonies) in 
different states are generally the similar but not identical (I.E. In PA, 
my home state, unbeknownst to almost everyone we do have "stand your 
ground", but it's only in play if the defendant can *prove* he was 
acting as in defense of an immediate threat on his safety or his family's 
safety. In Florida SYG is much less rigid (and that's why it's so 
controversial). You simply have to prove you were threatened or afraid, but 
not in immediate danger)  keep that in mind, I'm incredibly confident in my 
knowledge of PA/NY/NJ criminal codes, but Florida's could be a little 
different. So I could be a little off.... But.

1.)There were no grounds for a mistrial, and a mistrial is never ideal for 
the state. I mean not just the prosecutor, the whole Florida DAs office. 
Especially if it's dismissed *with* *prejudice* (can't be retried) That 
just didn't happen; mistrials only occur when due process is irreparably 
disrupted. You can't ask for a mistrial simply because a DA screwed up his 
case and he wants to use it to get around double jeapordy. If the 
defense causes a mistrial, it's usually w.o. prejudice, and the state has 
the green light to go again. But even then, *typically* the DA wants to 
speed cases up and the defense wants to slow them down (because time ruins 
a lot of cases. Wittnesses move away, evidence degrades, the impact dies 
down, maybe even the victim's family moves on. If I'm a DA and there's a 
murder, I want the defendant in front of a jury, ASAP. If I'm the defense 
I'm filing 20 motions and 30 continuances).

2.) Premeditated murder doesn't simply mean he went to the gas station with 
the intent to kill somebody. An offender can "premeditate" for 5 months or 
5 minutes. It's a little ironic, the classic example of non-premeditated 
murder (manslaughter, the guy who sees his wife in bed with another guy) 
may or may not be legit. If he thought his wife was being rapes, legit. If 
he flew into a violent rage and didn't mean to kill him, legit. If he 
shoots the guy point blank out of jealousy, not legit. Here the defendant 
got into an altercation, took out a gun, and fired it into a car. He knew 
what he was doing, he knew it could kill somebody, and he knew it was 
wrong. In PA and NY, That's murder 1. Whether it took him 10 minutes or 60 
seconds to go get his gun, it's still murder 1.

To your point, the DA absolutely could have put man 1 or murder 2 on the 
dockett, and probably could have gotten it. We'll never know why he didn't, 
but if you'll allow to me to speculate, sometimes when a DA's presented 
with a touchy case like this, he doesn't want to give the jury a "way out". 
They might just settle for man 1, because it's easier. Essentially he was 
trying to make the jury give him the needle, and it backfired. He 
overplayed his hand, people are very hesitant to convict on murder 1, 
especially when the death penalty's in play.  

Do we fault the ADA trying the case for that for that? Maybe, but 
hindsight's 20/20. And I'm pretty sure the DA will be appointing a new 
guy to retry the case after the deadlock. His career's going to take a hit 
regardless. Even if he does run for office, or a seat on the bench, or try 
to go into private practice, he'll always be the guy who didn't convict 
Michael Dunn.

3.) Quite simply, if a death occurs during the commission of a felony, it's 
homicide. That's why these "attempted murder" verdicts where somebody died 
make no sense, but again you can't appeal a jury's verdict.    

*Luckily* for the state, the jury didn't acquit. They were deadlocked. 
Which means the prosecution, but they can't bring him up on new charges. If 
they decide to go at him again, they can't say "oh well, I don't think we 
can get murder 1, let's try man 1". It's the original charge or no charge. 
With all the controversy around FL's SYG laws, I wouldn't be surprised to 
see this case retried, and soon this issue will hit the supreme court. FL's 
taking A LOT of heat, and not just in the media. It's starting to hit their 
economy.

top_comment.text:
You know I think making this about music per se sorta misses the point.

FIrstly yes shooting him was obviously unjustified, but to portray this as 
a random psychopathic murder is wrong as well. If you ask someone to turn 
down music, the polite & reasonable thing to do is to comply,

The fact that the kid refused a simple request shows that he was was not 
exactly completely innocent either.

This the equivalent of someone spitting in your face, & you shooting him 
after being provoked.

Still yes perhaps he deserves to be convicted for second degree murder, 
possibly with a partial defence of provocation, depending on how the kid 
reacted, e.g. if he was being particularly aggressive & threatened Dunn

But the way this is being portrayed I think skews & sensationalizes the 
case in a way that the left perpetually accuses the right of doing. It is 
unfair for any of us to make this case an open & shut case about a cranky 
old man killing an innocent kid for no reason.

For all we know Dunn could have made a completely reasonable request to 
start off with & Davis could have been the one acting like an unreasonable 
obnoxious turd

Let's not forget that a)Dunn was still convicted of a lesser charge and b) 
as Jarret stated, Lemon, nor any one of the people commenting was involved 
in the case,

Honestly I absolutely hate this kind of  arm chair quarterbacking on legal 
cases. They are complex & more often than not this kind of over simplistic 
commentary does not do them justice (pardon the pun)

Worse is when either side of politics tries to use them as political cudgel 
to score points, The right is reprehensible for trying to use legal cases 
to push tough on crime messages & although less frequent, it is becoming 
more common that the left is trying to use these cases to push some racial 
message (e.g this case & the Zimmerman case).

Individual cases are no different from anecdotal evidence, one case 
perhaps, but not something you should use to draw any sort of trend from, 
Only aggregate evidence should do that.﻿

Has everyone's brains fallen out?

This jury CONVICTED on three 2nd degree attempted murders.  Why would they

degree murder? Rather than Guilty / Not Guilty of murder completely?

top_comment.author: geodgereturns

comments.text:
+Caleb Meilink-Smith

I watched the Lemon broadcast.  He was frustrated with the judge being 
wishy-washy in his instructions and what they imply in terms of 
self-defense or stand-your-ground.  Lemon also kept harkening back to the 
question "whether it was ok to shoot" when the shooter is the aggressor, or 
when the shooter makes no attempt to de-escalate, or when we can't even 
come to "some consensus on whether someone is guilty of murdering a 
teenager because his music was too damn loud?" 

And to repeat, *if* the jury couldn't agree on which murder charge best 
applies, that means they *were not* debating over any of the issues Lemon 
was all worked up about.  (I say *if* because others have come to that 
opinion and it's the only conclusion that makes sense given the three 
attempted murder in the 2nd degree convictions this jury also handed down.  
I haven't found any reports definitively confirming this is the issue the 
jury split over.)

1st degree murder and 2nd degree murder are both, equally, not okay to 
shoot crimes.  Both are murder, period.  In other words, to all those 
issues infuriating Lemon regarding flimsy justifications for "whether it 
was ok to shoot" a teen who mouths off, or "ok to shoot" a teen who won't 
turn his music down, or "ok to shoot" when you've made zero attempt to just 
mind-your-own business about the car parked next to you?  The answer would 
be, even with a 2nd degree murder conviction, is "No. It Is Not Okay to do 
any of that stuff."

The problem with a hung jury is that legally there's been no progress 
whatsoever.  It's like the trial hasn't even taken place yet for that 
charge.  But it also does NOT mean that anybody on this jury said it was in 
any way, shape, or form OK to shoot that boy.
comments.author: geodgereturns

comments.text:
Whether or not jurors believe it, the main difference in reason for the two 
charges is whether someone is consciously aware that they are killing 
someone, in second degree it's more the matter of someone panicking. He

The point that it's still a life sentence is not the problem most people 
have. It's more of a principle, not the fact that he won't be facing

comments.author: Caleb Meilink-Smith

comments.text:
+Caleb Meilink-Smith

I don't necessarily disagree that he seemed like somebody almost eager to 
shoot people who piss him off.  But this wasn't a capital case-the 
prosecutor wasn't seeking the death penalty.  So the difference between 2nd 
and 1st conviction in his case is that he spends a *minimum* of 25 years in 
prison vs life sentence for that charge alone, and he's facing minimum 
concurrent sentences on the other 3, meaning it's life in prison anyway.  
And pushing for 1st increases the odds of a mistrial because it is a more 
potentially confusing (in this case anyway) application.  You don't have to 
be psychic to predict it will be much harder to find 12 jurors in gun crazy 
Florida who agree 10 seconds of fury constitutes "premeditation".

My point is there's a world of difference between jurors who don't see 10 
seconds as long enough to convict on 1st and jurors who "think it's okay to 
shoot people who don't turn down their music."  2nd degree murder *is* 
murder.  And all it takes is one hold out who goes against the others to 
say it *was* premeditated, or *wasn't* premeditated, and you will fail to 
get a conviction on either charge.

comments.text:
+Loakum


The difference between 1st and 2nd hinges on whether there was 
premeditation to kill a specific person *before* the act, not behavior 
*after* the fact.  There are only special circumstances where 1st degree 
can be found when there's no evidence the killer planned the killing of a 
specific person in advance.  Such as the killing of a police officer, 
carjacking, home invasion, setting a bomb, etc and so which of these 
special circumstances was applied in this case?  2nd degree applies in the 
"heat of the moment" situations, like fights between random strangers, when 
the killer was "evincing a depraved mind regardless of human life" and 
there's no evidence of "premeditated design to effect the death of any 
particular individual".

So does ten seconds constitute "premeditation"?  Is the random stranger #4 
in the back seat a "specific person" while the random strangers #1, #2, and 
#3 also in the car qualify as "not any particular individual"?

Dunn was also charged with attempted 1st degree murder of the 3 survivors, 
while the jury convicted on the lesser, 2nd degree charges.

comments.text:
+Plato86 Hello Plato86, good to see your comments here as always. I can 
shed a little light on this subject as I am a native of Jacksonville 
Florida for 36 years and have had personal experience with the Duval County 
''justice'' system. I can speak about the conditions of the jail downtown 
and the prison farm, but not the state penitentiary. The only time 
prisoners are segregated are in the instances of federal crimes or murder. 
There is a suicide block on the 6th floor, where inmates are confined to 
one cell with no time out except for showering or court. It used to be two 
inmates to a cell but that may have since changed. However, inmates are 
completely nude and only get a mattress and blanket. No socks, sheets or 
pillows allowed. General population is entirely integrated though, and it 
is the same at the prison farm. But at the p-farm, dorms house over a 
hundred inmates in each and there are no cells, only bunk beds. It is a 
wide-open space. There is a cafeteria where everyone is escorted during 
chow-time. At the county jail the food is brought to inmates, and in 
general population the cells are open and there are 30 minute rec-times, 
but it's not technically outside as there are high walls and a ceiling. As 
I said though, I don't know how things are done in the state pen. Pretty 
much the only time someone is segregated is whenever they are deemed a 
biohazard due to disease. Other than that, everyone is together. I hope 
this info gives a little clarity. Take care. By the way, Dunn will have to 
watch his back for a long time unless it's decided he should be protected, 
which I hope never happens for him. This should not have been a mistrial 
and the ''stand your ground'' defense should have never applied here.
